CASE NOTES Exemptions from operation of Article 3.  Article 3 of the Virginia Administrative Process Act, §§ 2.2-4018 through 2.2-4023, was inapplicable to the Commissioner of the Virginia Department of Labor and Industrys exercise of discretion under the Virginia Payment of Wage Act, subsection F of § 40.1-29, regarding an unpaid wage claim, because the Wage Payment Act satisfied the due process requirement. Mar v. Malveaux, 60 Va. App. 759, 732 S.E. 2d 733, 2012 Va. App. LEXIS 321 (2012).

akn:section.akn:heading: Informal fact finding proceedings

akn:content.akn:p: Text A. Agencies sh all ascertain the fact basis for their decisions of cases through informal conference or consultation proceedings unless the named party and the agency consent to waive such a conference or proceeding to go directly to a formal hearing. Such conference-c onsultation procedures shall include rights of parties to the case to (i) have reasonable notice thereof, which notice shall include contact information consisting of the name, telephone number, and government email address of the person designated by th e agency to answer questions or otherwise assist a named party; (ii) appear in person or by counsel or other qualified representative before the agency or its subordinates, or before a hearing officer for the informal presentation of factual data, argume nt, or proof in connection with any case; (iii) have notice of any contrary fact basis or information in the possession of the agency that can be relied upon in making an adverse decision; (iv) receive a prompt decision of any application for a license, benefit, or renewal thereof; and (v) be informed, briefly and generally in writing, of the factual or procedural basis for an adverse decision in any case. B. Agencies ma y, in their case decisions, rely upon public data, documents or information only when the agencies have provided all parties with advance notice of an intent to consider such public data, documents or information. This requirement shall not apply to an a gencys reliance on case law and administrative precedent. History History. 1975, c. 503, § 9-6.14:11; 1986, c. 615; 1989, c. 601; 1993, c . 898; 1994, c. 748; 1995, c. 398; 2001, c. 844; 2016, c. 39. Annotations Cross references. As to issuance of a special order by the Commissioner of Social Services, following a proceeding as provided in § 2.2-4019, for violations of the provisions of § 63.2-1700 et seq., § 54.1-3408, or regulations adopted under § 63.2-1700 et seq., see § 63.2-1709.2. The 2016 amendments. The 2016 amendment by c. 39 inserted which notice shall include contact information consisting of the name, telephone number, and government email address of the person designated by the agency to answer questions or otherwise assist a named party; in clause (i) of subsection A. Law Review. For survey of the Virginia law on administrative law for the year 2007-2008, see 43 U. Rich. L. Rev. 73 (2008). Research References. Friends Virginia Pleading and Practice (Matthew Bender). Chapter 3 Venue. § 3.03 Preferred (Category A) Venue. Friend. Michies Jurisprudence. For related discussion, see 1A M.J. Administrative Law, §§ 19, 20; 9B M.J. Hospita ls and Sanitariums, § 4. CASE NOTES Editors note. Some of the cases below were decided under former corresponding provisions. Former § 9-6.14:11 (see now this section and § 2.2-4021) and former § 9-6.14:12 (see now §§ 2.2-4020, 2.2-4021) are designed to bring cases to final decision at the agency level. State Bd. of Health v. Virginia Hosp. Ass'n, 1 Va. App. 5, 332 S.E.2d 793, 1985 Va. App. LEXIS 52 (1985). Construction with § 2.2-4020.  Subsection B of § 2.2-4020, dealing with formal hearings, contains explanatory requirement language apparently more expansive than that contained in clause (v) of subsection A of § 2.2-4019, dealing with informal hearings. Pursuant to the former, subsection E of § 2.2-4020 requires that a decision must briefly state the findings, conclusions, reasons or basis therefor upon the evidence presented and rele vant to the basic law under which the agency is operating. Va. Ret. Sys. v. Cirillo, 54 Va. App. 193, 676 S.E.2d 368, 2009 Va. App. LEXIS 228 (2009). Board for Contractors did not err in finding that the contractor violated the administrative code by failing to obtain a building permit before beginning work and burying footings before they were inspected because the Boards basic laws provided the contractor an informal fact-finding conference under this statute, but did not expressly call for a formal hearing under § 2.2-4020. JES Constr., LLC v. Bd. fo r Contrs., Dep't of Prof'l & Occupational Regulation, 2018 Va. App. LEXIS 361 (Va. Ct. App. Dec. 26, 2018). Nothing in the Virginia Administrative Process Act limits number of fact-finding conferences to one. Surprenant v. Board for Contractors, 30 Va. App. 165, 516 S.E.2d 220, 1999 Va. App. LEXIS 421 (1999). Initial determination defined.  Date on which the Virginia Department of Medical Assistance Services held its first informal factfinding conference (IFFC) with a corporation that was allegedly o verpaid under the Medicaid program, governed the issue of whether the Department was barred by § 32.1-325.1:1 from recovering overpayments; the trial courts judgment finding that the Department could not recover payments made more than four years before it held its first IFFC was upheld, even though a cost analyst sent a Notice of Program Reimbursement to the corporation within four years after each overpayment was made. Finnerty v. Thornton Hall, Inc., 42 Va. App. 628, 593 S.E.2d 568, 2004 Va. A pp. LEXIS 100 (2004). No right to cros s-examination in informal hearings.  That a real estate appraiser was not able to cross examine witnesses at her license revocation hearing did not deprive her of due process. Section 2.2-4020, provi ding for cross-examination of witnesses, was inapplicable, because she had an informal hearing under § 2.2-4019, which did not entitle her to cross-examine witnesses or force them to testify under oath. Haley v. Commonwealth, 2006 Va. App. LEXIS 441 ( Va. Ct. App. Oct. 3, 2006). Right to notice of contrary facts.  The requirement in clause (iii) of subsection A of § 2.2-4019 that an agency provide a party with notice of contrary facts was a right that only the party was allowed to assert. Furthermore, trial court properly held that a departments letter regarding the classification of business parks facility as a materials recovery facility was a case decision because the mailing of the letter to the business par k was sufficient service, and the author of the letter had authority to issue a case decision; finally, contrary to the departments claim, the informal meeting at issue had a presiding officer. Frederick County Bus. Park, LLC v. Va. Dep't of Envtl. Q uality, 52 Va. App. 40, 660 S.E.2d 698, 2008 Va. App. LEXIS 244 (2008), aff'd, 278 Va. 207, 677 S.E.2d 42, 2009 Va. LEXIS 64 (2009). Notice requirements.  Circuit court erred in suspending the revocation of a real estate agents license because the Real Estate Board of the Commonwealth of Virginia did not violate d the agents procedural due process rights when a reasonable reading of the initial notice clearly indicated that the agents prior criminal record would be before the Board and that it was actually required to consider it; the initial notice set forth the agents rights pursuant to the Virginia Administrative Process Act, subsection A of § 2.2-4019, the grounds for disciplinary actions under 18 VAC 135-20-155, the actual language of § 54.1-204, and the fact that the Board was required t o consider the provisions of § 54.1-204 in making its determination. Commonwealth v. DeLapp, 2010 Va. App. LEXIS 405 (Va. Ct. App. Oct. 19, 2010). Standard of review.  Whether reviewing the Commissioners decision as if a formal proceeding had been conducted pursuant to former § 9-6.14:12 (see now §§ 2.2-4020, 2.2-40 21) or an informal proceeding conducted pursuant to this section, the circuit court was required to determine whether the Commissioner had complied with statutory or legal authority in reaching his decision. Roanoke Mem. Hosps. v. Kenley, 3 Va. App. 599, 352 S.E.2d 525, 3 Va. Law Rep. 1607, 1987 Va. App. LEXIS 145 (1987). Retirement systems violation of clause (v) of subsection A of § 2.2-4019, by depriving the trial court of the rationale of the administrative decision, imp eded that court in the application of the substantive evidence rule in reviewing that decision. As a consequence, a benefits applicants right to an appropriate review by a circuit court was, likewise, compromised by the violation. Va. Ret. Sys. v. Ci rillo, 54 Va. App. 193, 676 S.E.2d 368, 2009 Va. App. LEXIS 228 (2009). Burden of proof.  Virginia Real Estate Boards finding that a broker violated an administrative regulation by failing to obtain the written consent of a seller prior to advertis ing real estate properties for sale was appropriate because the Board did not improperly place the burden of proof on the broker at an agency hearing. There was no unfair burden shifting in the broker attempting to overcome a prima facie showing of lack of written consent to advertise by presenting evidence of consent that was accepted and considered. Finch v. Commonwealth, 2019 Va. App. LEXIS 43 (Va. Ct. App. Feb. 26, 2019). Authority to begin administr ative process.  Despite an assisted living facilitys lack of an application for a permit for a waterworks, the Virginia Department of Health was within its authority under Vi rginia Administrative Process Act to begin the administrative process and eventually issue a case decision determining that such a permit was necessary because the facility, as the owner of a waterworks, was not able to operate without a permit. North Vi ew Home for Adults, LLC v. Va. Dep't of Health, 2021 Va. App. LEXIS 82 (Va. Ct. App. May 18, 2021). Error for failing to explain reason for denial of benefits was not harmless error.  Virginia Retirement System (VRS) committed a procedural error of law for failing to adequately comply with the explanatory requirements of clause (v) of subsectio n A of § 2.2-4019; that is, by failing to provide in writing the factual or procedural basis for an adverse decision. That failure required remand, pursuant to § 2.2-4027, because the error was not merely harmless error; the applicant could not hav e known which of three potential rationales for denial in subsection E of § 51.1-156 the VRS based its decision on when de...

akn:section.akn:heading: Formal hearings; litigated issues

akn:content.akn:p: Text A. The agency shall afford opportunity for the formal taking of evidence upon relevant fact issues in any case in which the basic laws provide expressly for decisions upon or after hearing and may do so in any case to the extent that informal procedures under § 2.2 -4019 have not been had or have failed to dispose of a case by consent. B. Parties to formal proceedings shall be given reasonable notice of the (i) time, place, and nature thereof; (ii) basic law under which the agency contemplates its possible exercise of authority; (iii) matters of fact and law asserted or questioned by the agency; and (iv) contact information consisting of the name, telephone number, and government email address of the person designated by the agency to respond to questions or otherwise assist a named party. Applicants for licenses, rights, benefits, or renewals ther eof have the burden of approaching the agency concerned without such prior notice but they shall be similarly informed thereafter in the further course of the proceedings whether pursuant to this section or to § 2.2-4019. C. In all such formal proceedings the parties shall be entitled to be accompanied by and represented by counsel, to submit oral and documentary evidence and rebuttal proofs, to conduct such cross-examination as may elicit a full and fair disclosure of the facts, and t o have the proceedings completed and a decision made with dispatch. The burden of proof shall be upon the proponent or applicant. The presiding officers at the proceedings may (i) administer oaths and affirmations, (ii) receive probative evidence, exclud e irrelevant, immaterial, insubstantial, privileged, or repetitive proofs, rebuttal, or cross-examination, rule upon offers of proof, and oversee a verbatim recording of the evidence, (iii) hold conferences for the settlement or simplification of issues by consent, (iv) dispose of procedural requests, and (v) regulate and expedite the course of the hearing. Where a hearing officer presides, or where a subordinate designated for that purpose presides in hearings specified in subsection F of § 2.2-4024 , he shall recommend findings and a decision unless the agency shall by its procedural regulations provide for the making of findings and an initial decision by the presiding officers subject to review and reconsideration by the agency on appeal to it as of right or on its own motion. The agency shall give deference to findings by the presiding officer explicitly based on the demeanor of witnesses. D. Prior to th e recommendations or decisions of subordinates, the parties concerned shall be given opportunity, on request, to submit in writing for the record (i) proposed findings and conclusions and (ii) statements of reasons therefor. In all cases, on request, opp ortunity shall be afforded for oral argument (a) to hearing officers or subordinate presiding officers, as the case may be, in all cases in which they make such recommendations or decisions or (b) to the agency in cases in which it makes the original dec ision without such prior recommendation and otherwise as it may permit in its discretion or provide by general rule. Where hearing officers or subordinate presiding officers, as the case may be, make recommendations, the agency shall receive and act on e xceptions thereto. E. All decisio ns or recommended decisions shall be served upon the parties, become a part of the record, and briefly state or recommend the findings, conclusions, reasons, or basis therefor upon the evidence presented by the record and relevant to the basic law under which the agency is operating together with the appropriate order, license, grant of benefits, sanction, relief, or denial thereof. History History. 1975, c. 503, § 9-6.14:12; 1986, c. 615; 1991, c. 584; 1993, c . 898; 1995, c. 398; 2001, c. 844; 2016, cc. 39, 694. Annotations Cross references. As to interpreters for the deaf in agency proceedings, see § 2.2-3400 et seq. Editors note. Acts 2016, c. 694, cl. 3 provides: That the Department of Human Resource Management shall submit a report by November 1 of each year to the Senate Committee o n General Laws and Technology and the House Committee on General Laws detailing (i) the number of employee grievance hearings held pursuant to the Administrative Process Act (§ 2.2-4000 et seq. of the Code of Virginia) and (ii) the number of decisions from such hearings that were rendered in favor of employees. The 2016 amendments. The 2016 amendment by c. 39 added clause (iv) in subsection B and made related changes. The 2016 amendment by c. 694, in subsection D, substituted (a) for (i), and (b) for (ii); and deleted or decisions followi ng make recommendations. Research References. Friends Virginia Pleading and Practice (Matthew Bender). Chapter 3 Venue. § 3.03 Preferred (Category A) Venue. Friend. Michies Jurisprudence. For related discussion, see 1A M.J. Administrative Law, §§ 10, 11, 13, 19. CASE NOTES Editors note. Some of the cases below were decided under former corresponding provisions. Former §§ 9-6.14:11 and 9-6.14:12 (see now §§ 2.2-4019 to 2.2-4021) are designed to bring cases to final decision at the agency level. State Bd. of Health v. Virginia Hosp. Ass'n, 1 Va. App. 5, 332 S.E.2d 793, 1985 Va. App. LEXIS 52 (1985). Right to a formal hearing is governed by the Virginia Administrative Process Act and the basic law (§ 62.1-44.2 et seq.). Environmental Defense Fund v. Virginia State Water Control Bd., 12 Va. App. 456, 404 S.E.2d 728, 7 Va. Law Rep. 2575, 1991 Va. App. LEXIS 100 (1991). Former § 9-6.14:12 (see now this section and § 2.2-4021) does not mandate formal hearing s where basic law does not.  Where basic law (§ 62.1-44.2 et seq.) does not expressly provide for issuance of Virginia Pollutant Discharge Elimination System (VPDES) permits only upon or a fter formal hearings, formal hearings are not mandatory under former § 9-6.14:12 (see now this section and § 2.2-4021). Environmental Defense Fund v. Virginia State Water Control Bd., 12 Va. App. 456, 404 S.E.2d 728, 7 Va. Law Rep. 2575, 1991 Va. A pp. LEXIS 100 (1991). Construction with § 2.2-4019.  Subsection B of § 2.2-4020, dealing with formal hearings, contains explanatory requirement language apparently more expansive than that contained in clause (v) of subsection A of § 2.2-4019, dealing with informal hearings. Pursuant to the former, subsection E of § 2.2-4020 requires that a decision must briefly state the findings, conclusions, reasons or basis therefor upon the evidence presented and rele vant to the basic law under which the agency is operating. Va. Ret. Sys. v. Cirillo, 54 Va. App. 193, 676 S.E.2d 368, 2009 Va. App. LEXIS 228 (2009). Despite the apparently less explanatory language requirement in § 2.2-4019, a trial courts opinions concerning § 2.2-4020 were persuasive because the un derlying statutory principle in both was the same: an administrative agency must offer a basis for its decision, understandable to a party and capable of proper review by a court. Va. Ret. Sys. v. Cirillo, 54 Va. App. 193, 676 S.E.2d 368, 2009 Va. App. L EXIS 228 (2009). Initial determination defined.  Date on which the Virginia Department of Medical Assistance Services held its first informal factfinding conference (IFFC) with a corporation that was allegedly o verpaid under the Medicaid program, governed the issue of whether the Department was barred by § 32.1-325.1:1 from recovering overpayments; the trial courts judgment finding that the Department could not recover payments made more than four years before it held its first IFFC was upheld, even though a cost analyst sent a Notice of Program Reimbursement to the corporation within four years after each overpayment was made. Finnerty v. Thornton Hall, Inc., 42 Va. App. 628, 593 S.E.2d 568, 2004 Va. A pp. LEXIS 100 (2004). Procedural due process.  Where the board: (1) afforded the doctor a formal hearing; (2) considered evidence from both the Attorney General and the doctor; (3) found that the doctors m isconduct led to the performance of unnecessary medical procedures, physical harm to patients, and death in one case; (4) and determined that the doctor violated several regulations, the board was authorized to conclude that the doctor posed a continuing threat to public health. The board had afforded the doctor the required procedural due process of notice and an opportunity to be heard regarding the charges against the doctor. Vuyyuru v. Va. Bd. of Med., 2008 Va. App. LEXIS 30 (Va. Ct. App. Jan. 15, 2 008). Circuit court properly affirmed a decision by the Virginia Alcoholic Beverage Control Board suspending a licensees liquor license because the hearing officer did not exceed her administrative and statutory powers where her questions to a liquor board agent and to an underage buyer on behalf of the agent, if erroneous, were harmless and did not violate the licensees procedural due process rights inasmuch a s the questions did not demonstrate bias or partiality and the licensee conceded that the evidence was overwhelming. Mall Amusements, LLC v. Va. Dep't of Alcoholic Bev. Control, 66 Va. App. 605, 790 S.E.2d 245, 2016 Va. App. LEXIS 237 (2016). The Virginia Board of Medicines denial of a doctors motion for a second continuance of an administrative hearing did not deprive the doctor of the doctor s due process right to counsel of the doctors choosing. The doctors right to counsel of the doctors choosing was not absolute, and the Board was entitled to exercise its discretion in weighing various other factors relevant to the decisio n, including the availability of substitute counsel, a quorum of the Board, and witnesses. Va. Bd. of Med. v. Hagmann, 67 Va. App. 488, 797 S.E.2d 422, 2017 Va. App. LEXIS 80 (2017). Virginia Board of Medicine properly revoked a doctors license to practice medicine because the Board did not violate the due process rights of the doctor by d enying the doctors motion for a second...

akn:section.akn:heading: Timetable for decision; exemptions

akn:content.akn:p: Text A. In cases wh ere a board or commission meets to render (i) an informal fact-finding decision or (ii) a decision on a litigated issue, and information from a prior proceeding is being considered, persons who participated in the prior proceeding shall be provided an op portunity to respond at the board or commission meeting to any summaries of the prior proceeding prepared by or for the board or commission. B. In any info rmal fact-finding, formal proceeding, or summary case decision proceeding in which a hearing officer is not used or is not empowered to recommend a finding, the board, commission, or agency personnel responsible for rendering a decision shall render that decision within 90 days from the date of the informal fact-finding, formal proceeding, or completion of a summary case decision proceeding, or from a later date agreed to by the named party and the agency. If the agency does not render a decision within 90 days, the named party to the case decision may provide written notice to the agency that a decision is due. If no decision is made within 30 days from agency receipt of the notice, the decision shall be deemed to be in favor of the named party. The p receding sentence shall not apply to case decisions before (i) the State Water Control Board or the Department of Environmental Quality to the extent necessary to comply with the federal Clean Water Act, (ii) the State Air Pollution Control Board or the Department of Environmental Quality to the extent necessary to comply with the federal Clean Air Act, or (iii) the Virginia Soil and Water Conservation Board or the Department of Conservation and Recreation to the extent necessary to comply with the fede ral Clean Water Act. An agency shall provide notification to the named party of its decision within five days of the decision. C. In any info rmal fact-finding, formal proceeding, or summary case decision proceeding in which a hearing officer is empowered to recommend a finding, the board, commission, or agency personnel responsible for rendering a decision shall render that decision within 30 days from the date that the agency receives the hearing officers recommendation. If the agency does not render a decision within 30 days, the named party to the case decision may provide written notice to the agency that a decision is due. If no dec ision is made within 30 days from agency receipt of the notice, the decision is deemed to be in favor of the named party. The preceding sentence shall not apply to case decisions before (i) the State Water Control Board or the Department of Environmental Quality to the extent necessary to comply with the federal Clean Water Act, (ii) the State Air Pollution Control Board or the Department of Environmental Quality to the extent necessary to comply with the federal Clean Air Act, or (iii) the Virginia Soi l and Water Conservation Board or the Department of Conservation and Recreation to the extent necessary to comply with the federal Clean Water Act. An agency shall provide notice to the named party of its decision within five days of the decision. D. The provisi ons of subsection B notwithstanding, if the board members or agency personnel who conducted the informal fact-finding, formal proceeding, or summary case decision proceeding are unable to attend to official duties due to sickness, disability, or terminat ion of their official capacity with the agency, then the timeframe provisions of subsection B shall be reset and commence from the date that either new board members or agency personnel are assigned to the matter or a new proceeding is conducted if neede d, whichever is later. An agency shall provide notice within five days to the named party of any incapacity of the board members or agency personnel that necessitates a replacement or a new proceeding. History History. 1975, c. 503, §§ 9-6.14:11, 9-6.14:12; 1986, c. 615; 1989, c. 601; 1991, c. 584; 1993, c. 898; 1994, c. 748; 1995, c. 398; 2001, c. 844; 2005, c. 102; 2006, c. 702. Annotations Cross references. As to interpreters for the deaf in agency proceedings, see § 2.2-3400 et seq. Michies Jurisprudence. For related discussion, see 1A M.J. Administrative Law, §§ 10, 11. The 2005 amendments. The 2005 amendment by c. 102, in subsection B, in the fourth sentence, deleted or preceding (ii), inserted or and inserted clause (iii); i n C, in the fourth sentence, deleted or preceding (ii), inserted or and inserted clause (iii); and made minor stylistic changes. The 2006 amendments. The 2006 amendment by c. 702, in subsection B, deleted or preceding formal proceeding and inserted or summary case decision proceeding at the beginning of the first sentence, and deleted or preceding formal proceeding and inserted or completion of a summary case decision proceeding near the end of the first sentence; in subsection C, deleted or preceding formal proceeding and inserted or summary case decision proceeding in the first sentence; and in subsection D, deleted or preceding formal proceeding and inserted or summary case decision proceeding in the first se ntence. CASE NOTES Editors note. Some of the cases below were decided under former corresponding provisions. Former §§ 9-6.14:11 and 9-6.14:12 (see now § 2.2-4020) are designed to bring cases to final decision at the agency level. State Bd. of Health v. Virginia Hosp. Ass'n, 1 Va. App. 5, 332 S.E.2d 793, 1985 Va. App. LEXIS 52 (1985). Nothing in the Virginia Administrative Process Act limits number of fact-finding conferences to one. Surprenant v. Board for Contractors, 30 Va. App. 165, 516 S.E.2d 220, 1999 Va. App. LEXIS 421 (1999). Standard of review.  Whether reviewing the Commissioners decision as if a formal proceeding had been conducted pursuant to former § 9-6.14:12 (see now this section and § 2.2 -4020) or an informal proceeding conducted pursuant to this section, the circuit court was required to determine whether the Commissioner had complied with statutory or legal authority in reaching his decision. Roanoke Mem. Hosps. v. Kenley, 3 Va. App. 5 99, 352 S.E.2d 525, 3 Va. Law Rep. 1607, 1987 Va. App. LEXIS 145 (1987). Ninety-day period commenced when fact-finding conference held by Virginia Retirement System.  Ninety-day period for review of disability retirement benefits commenced when Virginia Retirement System (VRS) representative held informal fact-finding conferenc e, not when VRS received medical board report on claimants condition; agencys failure to render decision meant that decision was deemed to be in claimants favor 30 days after agency received notice from claimant that a decision was due. Rizzo v. Virginia Retirement Sys., 255 Va. 375, 497 S.E.2d 852, 1998 Va. LEXIS 36 (1998). Written notice that decision due.  Circuit court properly affirmed an order by the Virginia Board of Medicine that removed a stay of suspension of a doctors medical license because the doctor c onceded that he withdrew from monitoring and was not in compliance with monitoring order, the doctor failed to appeal the original suspension of his license and the conditional reinstatement of his license, the doctors letter to the Department of Hea lth Professionals regarding his difficulties in complying with the Board-ordered monitoring did not constitute written notice that a decision was due, and the Board was not required to revisit the validity of the prior orders regarding the doctors fa ilure to comply with the monitoring. Clowdis v. Va. Bd. of Med., 2018 Va. App. LEXIS 34 (Va. Ct. App. Feb. 13, 2018). Triggering of statutory deadlines.  Informal fact-finding conference rendered a decision within the time frame specified in the statute because nothing in an e-mail message a physician sent suggeste d to the Board that a decision was due as required to trigger the deeming provision of subsection C; the failure of the only writing cited by the physician to provide notice precluded any possibility that he could have been entitled to relief under subse ction C. Merchia v. Va. Bd. of Med., 2018 Va. App. LEXIS 334 (Va. Ct. App. Dec. 4, 2018). Initial interviews by investigators are just that, interviews; they do not trigger the statutory deadlines of subsection C. Merchia v. Va. Bd. of Med., 2018 Va. A pp. LEXIS 334 (Va. Ct. App. Dec. 4, 2018). Right to a formal hearing is governed by the Virginia Administrative Process Act and the basic law (§ 62.1-44.2 et seq.). Environmental Defense Fund v. Virginia State Water Control Bd., 12 Va. App. 456, 404 S.E.2d 728, 7 Va. Law Rep. 2575, 1991 Va. App. LEXIS 100 (1991). Former § 9-6.14:12 (see now this section and § 2.2-4020) does not mandate formal hearing s where basic law does not.  Where basic law (§ 62.1-44.2 et seq.) does not expressly provide for issuance of Virginia Pollutant Discharge Elimination System (VPDES) permits only upon or a fter formal hearings, formal hearings are not mandatory under former § 9-6.14:12 (see now this section and § 2.2-4020). Environmental Defense Fund v. Virginia State Water Control Bd., 12 Va. App. 456, 404 S.E.2d 728, 7 Va. Law Rep. 2575, 1991 Va. A pp. LEXIS 100 (1991). Procedural objection not waived.  The mere failure to mention issue during oral argument of the facts of the matter does not amount to a waiver of the procedural objection. This statute does not r equire the party who is the target of the proceeding to present oral argument before the board, or even to appear at the full board hearing. Virginia Bd. of Medicine v. Fetta, 244 Va. 276, 421 S.E.2d 410, 9 Va. Law Rep. 256, 1992 Va. LEXIS 91 (1992). Denial of application for a septic tank permit after formal hearing and informal rejecti on of post-hearing applications constituted agency case decision, but only the formal denial disposed of the litigated issue within the meaning of former § 9-6.14:12 (see now this section and § 2.2-4020). State Bd. of Health v. Godfrey, 223 Va. 423, 290 S.E.2d 875, 1982 Va. LEXIS 221 (1982). Determina...

akn:section.akn:heading: Subpoenas, depositions and requests for admissions

akn:content.akn:p: Text The agency or its designated subordinates may, and on request of any party to a case shall, issue subpoenas requiring testimony or the production of books, papers, and physical or other evidence. Any person so subpoenaed who objects may, if the agency does not quash or modify the subpoena at his timely request as illegally or improvidently granted, immediately procure by petition a decision on the validity thereof in t he circuit court as provided in § 2.2-4003; and otherwise in any case of refusal or neglect to comply with an agency subpoena, unless the basic law under which the agency is operating provides some other recourse, enforcement, or penalty, the agency m ay procure an order of enforcement from such court. Depositions de bene esse and requests for admissions may be directed, issued, and taken on order of the agency for good cause shown; and orders or authorizations therefor may be challenged or enforced i n the same manner as subpoenas. Nothing in this section shall be taken to authorize discovery proceedings. History History. 1975, c. 503, § 9-6.14:13; 2001, c. 844. Annotations Research References. Bryson on Virginia Civil Procedure (Matthew Bender). Chapter 9. Discovery. § 9.05 Depositions, etc. Bryson. Michies Jurisprudence. For related discussion, see 1A M.J. Administrative Law, §§ 10, 11. CASE NOTES Right to subpoena.  Former § 9-6.14:13 (see now this section) creates a statutory right, under certain conditions, to a subpoena in an administrative proceeding for parties theret o. State Health Dep't Sewage Handling & Disposal v. Britton, 15 Va. App. 68, 421 S.E.2d 37, 9 Va. Law Rep. 199, 1992 Va. App. LEXIS 236 (1992) (decided under prior law). Standard for quashing subpoe na duces tecum.  While the State Health Department Sewage Handling and Disposal Appeal Review Board may quash a subpoena as illegally or improvidently granted, it may not do so merely because it deems as too burdensome the requirement that it identify and produce relevant evidence. State Health Dep't Sewage Handling & Disposal v. Britton, 15 Va. App. 68, 421 S.E.2d 37, 9 Va. Law Rep. 199, 1992 Va. App. LEXIS 236 (1992) (d ecided under prior law). Appeal review board erred in quashing appellees subpoena duces tecum although the bo ard argued that the other permits appellee sought to subpoena had been illegally issued in violation of the regulations, and therefore, the evidence would not establish a legal basis for his entitlement to a permit. The statute does not deny a party acce ss to relevant evidence when, in the boards judgment, the otherwise relevant evidence might not convince it to act. While the evidence ultimately may not be sufficient to prove appellees entitlement, he has the right of access to relevant evidenc e in the boards possession and control and has the right to have it considered. State Health Dep't Sewage Handling & Disposal v. Britton, 15 Va. App. 68, 421 S.E.2d 37, 9 Va. Law Rep. 199, 1992 Va. App. LEXIS 236 (1992) (decided under prior law).

akn:section.akn:heading: Final orders

akn:content.akn:p: Text The terms of any final agency case decision, as signed by it, shall be served upon the named parties by mail unless service otherwise made is duly acknowledged by them in writing. The signed originals, which may be retained in an electronic medium in accordance with § 42.1-86.01, shall remain in the custody of the agency as public records subject to judicial notice by all courts and agencies; and they, or facsimiles thereof, together with the full record or file in every case shall be made available for public inspection or copying except (i) so far as the agency may withhold the same in whole or part for the purpose of protecting individuals mentioned from persona l embarrassment, obloquy, or disclosures of a private nature including statements respecting the physical, mental, moral, or financial condition of such individuals or (ii) for trade secrets or, so far as protected by other laws, other commercial or indu strial information imparted in confidence. Final orders may be recorded, enforced, and satisfied as orders or decrees of a circuit court upon certification of such orders by the agency head or his designee. History History. 1975, c. 503, § 9-6.14:14; 2001, c. 844; 2009, c. 797; 2022, c . 247. Annotations The 2009 amendments. The 2009 amendment by c. 797 added the last sentence. The 2022 amendments. The 2022 amendment by c. 247 inserted which may be retained in an electronic medium in accordance with § 42.1-86.01; and made stylistic changes. Law Review. For annual survey of Virginia law article, Administrative Law, see 47 U. Rich. L. Rev. 7 (2012). Research References. Friends Virginia Pleading and Practice (Matthew Bender). Chapter 39 Appeals to Circuit Courts. § 39.06 Appeals Under the Administrative Process Act. Friend . Michies Jurisprudence. For related discussion, see 1A M.J. Administrative Law, § 16. CASE NOTES Section deals only with duties of agencies.  Former § 9-6.14:14 (see now this section) does not deal with appeals but only with the duties of the various agencies. Occoquan Land Dev. Corp. v. Cooper, 239 Va. 363, 389 S.E.2d 464, 6 Va. Law Rep. 1574, 1990 Va. LEXIS 56 (1990) (decided under corresponding former provisions). Case decision.  Trial court properly held that a departments letter regarding the classification of business parks facility as a materials recovery facility was a case de cision and the mailing of the letter to the business park was sufficient service. Frederick County Bus. Park, LLC v. Va. Dep't of Envtl. Quality, 52 Va. App. 40, 660 S.E.2d 698, 2008 Va. App. LEXIS 244 (2008), aff'd, 278 Va. 207, 677 S.E.2d 42, 2009 Va. LEXIS 64 (2009). CIRCUIT COURT OPINIONS Additional time to file notice of appeal.  Neither a city, nor the city council were entitled to a mailed copy of the final decision of the Virginia Department of Environmental Qualitys to grant reques ted variances to Virginia solid waste management regulations, which would have given them three additional days during which to file a notice of appeal, because a final case decision was to be served upon the named parties by mail. City of Norfolk v. Va. Dep't of Envtl. Quality, 99 Va. Cir. 465, 2018 Va. Cir. LEXIS 140 (Norfolk Aug. 24, 2018). Service of final decision.  Circuit court denied a citys motion for reconsideration because it ultimately found persuasive the evidence presented by a lessor, a lessee, and the Virginia Department of Environmental Quality (DEQ) that service of the final decision to grant certain variances by DEQ on the lessor was made via mail and email; the city failed to satisfy its burden of production to present countervailing evidence that proper s ervice on the lessor had not been made. City of Norfolk v. Va. Dep't of Envtl. Quality, 99 Va. Cir. 465, 2018 Va. Cir. LEXIS 348 (Norfolk Oct. 16, 2018). § 2.2-4023.1. Reconsideration. Text A. A party may file a petition for reconsideration of an agencys final decision made pursuant to § 2.2-4020. The petition shall be filed with the agency not later than 15 days after service of the final decision and shall state the specific grounds on which rel ief is requested. The petition shall contain a full and clear statement of the facts pertaining to the reasons for reconsideration, the grounds in support thereof, and a statement of the relief desired. A timely filed petition for reconsideration shall n ot suspend the execution of the agency decision nor toll the time for filing a notice of appeal under Rule 2A:2 of the Rules of Supreme Court of Virginia, unless the agency provides for suspension of its decision when it grants a petition for reconsidera tion. The failure to file a petition for reconsideration shall not constitute a failure to exhaust all administrative remedies. B. The agency shall render a written decision on a partys timely petition for reconsideration within 30 days from receipt of the petition for reconsideration. Such decision shall (i) deny the petition, (ii) modify the case decision, or (iii) vacate the case decisi on and set a new hearing for further proceedings. The agency shall state the reasons for its action. C. If reconsid eration is sought for the decision of a policy-making board of an agency, such board may (i) consider the petition for reconsideration at its next regularly scheduled meeting; (ii) schedule a special meeting to consider and decide upon the petition withi n 30 days of receipt; or (iii) notwithstanding any other provision of law, delegate authority to consider the petition to either the board chairman, a subcommittee of the board, or the director of the agency that provides administrative support to the bo ard, in which case a decision on the reconsideration shall be rendered within 30 days of receipt of the petition by the board. D. Denial of a petition for reconsideration shall not constitute a separate case decision and shall not on its own merits be subject to judicial review. It may, however, be considered by a reviewing court as part of any judicial review of the case decision itself. E. The agency may reconsider its final decision on its own initiative for good cause within 30 days of the date of the final decision. An agency may develop procedures for reconsideration of its final decisions on its own initiative. F. Notwithstan ding the provisions of this section, (i) any agency may promulgate regulations that specify the scope of evidence that may be considered by such agency in support of any petition for reconsideration and (ii) any agency that has statutory authority for re consideration in its basic law may respond to requests in accordance with such law. History History. 2016, c. 694. Annotations Editors note. Acts 2016, c. 694, cl. 2 provides: That any agency which intends to promulgate regulations that specify the scope of evidence that may be considered by such a gency in support of any petition for reconsideration may promulgate emergency regulations to become effective within 280 days or less from the enactment of this act. Acts 2016, c. 694, cl. 3 provides: That the Department of Human Resource Management shall submit a report by November 1 of each year to the Senate Committee o n General Laws and Technology and the House Committee on General Laws detailing (i) the number of employee grievance hearings held pursuant to the Administrative Process Act (§ 2.2-4000 et seq. of the Code of Virginia) and (ii) the number of decisions from such hearings that were rendered in favor of employees. Article 4. Hearing Officers. -360§ 2.2-4024. Hearing officers. -360§ 2.2-4024.1. Disqualification. -360§ 2.2-4024.2. Ex parte communications.

akn:section.akn:heading: Hearing officers

akn:content.akn:p: Text A. In all form al hearings conducted in accordance with § 2.2-4020, the hearing shall be presided over by a hearing officer selected from a list prepared by the Executive Secretary of the Supreme Court and maintained in the Office of the Executive Secretary of the S upreme Court. Parties to informal fact-finding proceedings conducted pursuant to § 2.2-4019 may agree at the outset of the proceeding to have a hearing officer preside at the proceeding, such agreement to be revoked only by mutual consent. The Executi ve Secretary may promulgate rules necessary for the administration of the hearing officer system and shall have the authority to establish the number of hearing officers necessary to preside over administrative hearings in the Commonwealth.Prior to being included on the list, all hearing officers shall meet the following minimum standards: 1. Activ e membership in good standing in the Virginia State Bar; 2. Active practice of law for at least five years; and 3. Completion of a course of training approved by the Executive Secretary of the Supreme Court. In order to comply with the demonstrated requirements of the agency requesting a hearing of ficer, the Executive Secretary may require additional training before a hearing officer shall be assigned to a proceeding before that agency. B. On request from the head of an agency, the Executive Secretary shall name a hearing officer from the list, selected on a rotation system administered by the Executive Secretary. Lists reflecting geographic preference and specialized training or knowledge shall be m aintained by the Executive Secretary if an agency demonstrates the need. C. A hearing o fficer appointed in accordance with this section shall be subject to disqualification as provided in § 2.2-4024.1. If the hearing officer denies a petition for disqualification pursuant to § 2.2-4024.1, the petitioning party may request reconsidera tion of the denial by filing a written request with the Executive Secretary along with an affidavit, prior to the taking of evidence at a hearing, stating with particularity the grounds upon which it is claimed that a fair and impartial hearing cannot be accorded, or the applicable rule of practice requiring disqualification.The issue shall be determined not less than 10 days prior to the hearing by the Executive Secretary. D. Any hearing officer empowered by the agency to provide a recommendation or conclusion in a case decision matter shall render that recommendation or conclusion as follows: 1. If th e agencys written regulations or procedures require the hearing officer to render a recommendation or conclusion within a specified time period, the hearing officer shall render the recommendation or conclusion on or before the expiration of the spec ified period; and 2. In all other cases, the hearing officer shall render the recommendation or conclusion within 90 days from the date of the case decision proceeding or from a later date agreed to by the named party and the agency.If the hearing officer does not render a decision within the time required by this subsection, then the agency or the named party to the case decision may provide written notice to the hearing officer and the Executive Secreta ry of the Supreme Court that a decision is due. If no decision is made within 30 days from receipt by the hearing officer of the notice, then the Executive Secretary of the Supreme Court shall remove the hearing officer from the hearing officer list and report the hearing officer to the Virginia State Bar for possible disciplinary action, unless good cause is shown for the delay. E. The Executi ve Secretary shall remove hearing officers from the list, upon a showing of cause after written notice and an opportunity for a hearing. When there is a failure by a hearing officer to render a decision as required by subsection D, the burden shall be on the hearing officer to show good cause for the delay. Decisions to remove a hearing officer may be reviewed by a request to the Executive Secretary for reconsideration, followed by judicial review in accordance with this chapter. F. This sectio n shall not apply to hearings conducted by (i) any commission or board where all of the members, or a quorum, are present; (ii) the Virginia Alcoholic Beverage Control Authority, the Virginia Workers Compensation Commission, the State Corporation Com mission, the Virginia Employment Commission, the Department of Motor Vehicles under Title 46.2 (§ 46.2-100 et seq.), § 58.1-2409, or Chapter 27 (§ 58.1-2700 et seq.) of Title 58.1, or the Motor Vehicle Dealer Board under Chapter 15 (§ 46.2-15 00 et seq.) of Title 46.2; or (iii) any panel of a health regulatory board convened pursuant to § 54.1-2400, including any panel having members of a relevant advisory board to the Board of Medicine. All employees hired after July 1, 1986, pursuant to §§ 65.2-201 and 65.2-203 by the Virginia Workers Compensation Commission to conduct hearings pursuant to its basic laws shall meet the minimum qualifications set forth in subsection A. Agency employees who are not licensed to practice law in th e Commonwealth, and are presiding as hearing officers in proceedings pursuant to clause (ii) shall participate in periodic training courses. G. Notwithstan ding the exemptions of subsection A of § 2.2-4002, this article shall apply to hearing officers conducting hearings of the kind described in § 2.2-4020 for the Department of Wildlife Resources, the Virginia Housing Development Authority, the Milk C ommission, and the Virginia Resources Authority pursuant to their basic laws. History History. 1986, c. 615, § 9-6.14:14.1; 1988, c. 865; 1990, c. 219; 1991, c. 214; 1992, c. 659; 1993, c. 898; 1995, cc. 744, 776, 803, 805; 1996, cc. 189, 205, 639, 658; 2001, c. 844; 2002, cc. 448, 698; 2009, c. 806; 2012, cc. 803, 835; 2015, cc. 38, 636, 730; 2018, c. 613; 2020, c. 958. Annotations The 2012 amendments. The 2012 amendments by cc. 803 and 835, cl. 106, effective January 1, 2013, are identical, and made minor stylistic changes in subsection D; and deleted or th e Board of Towing and Recovery Operators under Chapter 28 (§ 46.2-2800 et seq.) of Title 46.2 preceding or (iii) near the middle of subsection F. The 2015 amendments. The 2015 amendments by cc. 38 and 730, effective January 15, 2018, are identical and substituted Virginia Alcoholic Beverage Control Authority for Alc oholic Beverage Control Board in subsection F. The 2015 amendment by c. 636, in subsection C, substituted appointed in accordance with this section shall be subject to disqualification as provided in § 2.2-4024.1. If the hearing officer denies a petition for disqualification pursuant to § 2.2-4024.1, the petitioning party may request reconsideration of the denial by filing a written request with the Executive Secretary along with for shall v oluntarily disqualify himself and withdraw from any case in which he cannot accord a fair and impartial hearing or consideration, or when required by the applicable rules governing the practice of law in the Commonwealth. Any party may request the disqua lification of a hearing officer by filing in the first paragraph, and deleted of the Supreme Court at the end of the second paragraph. The 2018 amendments. The 2018 amendment by c. 613 added as follows at the end of the introductory paragraph in subsection D; added subdivision D 1; in subdivision D 2, inserte d 2. In all other cases, the hearing officer shall render the recommendation or conclusion at the beginning; in the last paragraph of subsection D, substituted the time required by this subsection, then the agency or for 90 days, then . The 2020 amendments. The 2020 amendment by c. 958, substituted Department of Wildlife Resources for Department of Game and Inland Fisheries in subsection G. Research References. Bryson on Virginia Civil Procedure (Matthew Bender). Chapter 2 Potential Jurisdiction. § 2.03 Courts, etc. Bryson. CIRCUIT COURT OPINIONS Denial of due process.  When a Medicaid provider sought administrative review of a decision of the Virginia Department of Medical Assistance Services to retract funds paid to the provide r, the providers right to due process was violated because a hearing examiner improperly deferred to the Departments witness. Sentara Enters. v. Dep't of Med. Assistance Servs., 85 Va. Cir. 338, 2012 Va. Cir. LEXIS 178 (Norfolk Sept. 13, 2012). § 2.2-4024.1. Disqualification. Text A. An individu al who has served as investigator, prosecutor, or advocate at any stage in a contested case or who is subject to the authority, direction, or discretion of an individual who has served as investigator, prosecutor, or advocate at any stage in a contested case may not serve as the presiding officer or hearing officer in the same case. An agency head who has participated in a determination of probable cause or other preliminary determination in an adjudication may serve as the presiding officer in the adju dication unless a party demonstrates grounds for disqualification under subsection B. B. A presiding officer or hearing officer is subject to disqualification for any factor that would cause a reasonable person to question the impartiality of the presiding officer or hearing officer, which may include bias, prejudice, financial interest, or ex parte co mmunications; however, the fact that a hearing officer is employed by an agency as a hearing officer, without more, is not grounds for disqualification. The presiding officer or hearing officer, after making a reasonable inquiry, shall disclose to the pa rties all known facts related to grounds for disqualification that are material to the impartiality of the presiding officer or hearing officer in the proceeding. The presiding officer or hearing officer may self-disqualify and withdraw from any case for reasons listed in this subsection. C. A party may petition for the disqualification of the presiding officer or hearing off...

akn:section.akn:heading: Exemptions operation of this article; limitations

akn:content.akn:p: Text A. This articl e shall not apply to any agency action that (i) is placed beyond the control of the courts by constitutional or statutory provisions expressly precluding court review, (ii) involves solely the internal management or routine of an agency, (iii) is a decis ion resting entirely upon an inspection, test, or election save as to want of authority therefor or claim of arbitrariness or fraud therein, (iv) is a case in which the agency is acting as an agent for a court, or (v) encompasses matters subject by law t o a trial de novo in any court. B. The provisi ons of this article, however, shall apply to case decisions regarding the grant or denial of Temporary Assistance for Needy Families, Medicaid, food stamps, general relief, auxiliary grants, or state-local hospitalization. However, no appeal may be broug ht regarding the adequacy of standards of need and payment levels for public assistance and social services programs. Notwithstanding the provisions of § 2.2-4027, the review shall be based solely upon the agency record, and the court shall be limited to ascertaining whether there was evidence in the agency record to support the case decision of the agency acting as the trier of fact. If the court finds in favor of the party complaining of agency action, the court shall remand the case to the agency for further proceedings. The validity of any statute, regulation, standard or policy, federal or state, upon which the action of the agency was based shall not be subject to review by the court. No intermediate relief shall be granted under § 2.2-4028 . History History. 1975, c. 503, §§ 9-6.14:4.1, 9-6.14:15, 9-6.14:16; 1986, c. 615; 1989, cc. 677, 734; 2001, c. 844; 2002, c. 747. Annotations Cross references. As to appeals of certain actions of local departments of social services in civil proceedings involving alleged abuse or neglect of a child, see § 63.2-1526. The 2002 amendments. The 2002 amendment by c. 747, effective October 1, 2002, deleted former subsection B, relating to appeals from decisions of the Governors Employment and Train ing Department; redesignated former subsection C as present subsection B; and in present subsection B, substituted Temporary Assistance for Needy Families for aid to dependent children in the first sentence, and inserted and social se rvices near the end of the second sentence. Law Review. For survey of Virginia administrative law and utility regulation for the year 1978-1979, see 66 Va. L. Rev. 193 (1980). For comment,  Working to the Contract in Virginia: Legal Consequences of Teachers Attempts to Limit Their Contractual Duties, see 16 U. Rich. L. Rev. 449 (1982). Research References. Bryson on Virginia Civil Procedure (Matthew Bender). Chapter 2 Potential Jurisdiction. § 2.03 Courts, etc. Bryson. Friends Virginia Pleading and Practice (Matthew Bender). Chapter 38 Appeals to the Court of Appeals of Virginia. § 38.30 Appeals under the Administrative P rocess Act; Chapter 39 Appeals to Circuit Courts. § 39.06 Appeals Under the Administrative Process Act, et seq. Friend. Michies Jurisprudence. For related discussion, see 1A M.J. Administrative Law, §§ 10, 16. CASE NOTES Editors note. Some of the cases below were decided under former Title 2.1 or prior provisions. Review only at insiste nce of owner aggrieved.  Former § 9-6.14:15 (see now this section) prohibits judicial review of a boards decision at the insistence of any one other than an owner aggrieved.  Town of Fries v. State Water Control Bd., 13 Va. App. 213, 409 S.E.2d 634, 8 Va. Law Rep. 1093, 1991 Va. App. LEXIS 268 (1991). Legislative intent.  When the legislature created the trial de novo exclusion under former § 9-6.14:15 (see now this section), it contemplated agency actions whose subject matters were not subject to the standard of review set forth in former § 9-6.14:17 (see now § 2.2-4027). School Bd. v. Nicely, 12 Va. App. 1051, 408 S.E.2d 545, 8 Va. Law Rep. 367, 1991 Va. App. LEXIS 202 (1991). Failure to name proper party on appeal to circuit court.  Both former § 9-6.14:16 (see now this section and § 2.2-4026) and Supreme Court Rule 2A:1(b) require that the agency rendering a case decision be made a par ty to the judicial review proceeding; where such agency is not named, the appellants petition may be dismissed. Somers v. Accomack County Dep't of Soc. Servs., 2001 Va. App. LEXIS 291 (Va. Ct. App. May 29, 2001). An action brought pursuant to subsection D of § 22.1-214 (pertaining to provision of special education programs for handicapped children) amounts to a trial de novo for the purposes of clause (v) of former § 9-6.14:15 (see now this section), which excludes matters subject to trial de novo from the Virginia Administrative Process Act s provisions governing court review of agency decisions. School Bd. v. Nicely, 12 Va. App. 1051, 408 S.E.2d 545, 8 Va. Law Rep. 367, 1991 Va. App. LEXIS 202 (1991). Agencys action arbitrary a nd capricious.  Excavation company was entitled to recover reasonable costs and fees under this section where all issues in dispute were decided in its favor, the Department of M ines, Minerals & Energys actions were arbitrary and capricious (Department sought determination that removal of dirt was mining within meaning of § 45.1-180), and there were no special circumstances to render the award unjust. Commonwealth Dep't of Mines, Minerals & Energy v. May Bros., 11 Va. App. 115, 396 S.E.2d 695, 7 Va. Law Rep. 499, 1990 Va. App. LEXIS 170 (1990). Failure to comply with Virginia Supreme Court Rule 2A:4.  In a case in which a Medicaid claimant appealed a trial courts dismissal of his petition seeking review of a decision by the Virginia Department of Medical As sistance Services, the claimants indefinite allegations against the Alexandria Department of Human Services did not satisfy Va. Sup. Ct. R. 2A:4(b)s requirements that the petition for appeal specify the errors alleged and state the reasons why th e agencys case decision violated the law. Sudduth v. City of Alexandria Dep't of Human Servs., 2009 Va. App. LEXIS 466 (Va. Ct. App. Oct. 20, 2009). CIRCUIT COURT OPINIONS No appeal intervention.  Neighbor of landowner who appealed administrative decision concerning landowners land could not intervene in the appeal because she did not challenge the unla wfulness of the agency decision, but rather sought to preserve her interests, which had been obtained in the administrative procedure, and she was not an aggrieved person nor a necessary party. City of Norfolk Wetlands Bd. v. Va. Marine Res. Comm'n, 54 V a. Cir. 294, 2000 Va. Cir. LEXIS 599 (Norfolk Dec. 21, 2000) (decided under prior law). Reviewability of claim.  Spouses claim that a Medicaid eligibility worker failed to advise her that she should set funds aside for burial was not reviewed, as it was not submitted to the agency for consideration. Sherline v. Finnerty, 65 Va. Cir. 154, 2004 Va. Cir. LEXIS 143 (Fairfax County June 21, 2004). Failure to exhaust adminis trative remedies.  Owners suit seeking to enjoin a city from demolishing improvements on the owners property was barred because the owners failure to seek review provide d for by § 36-105 was a failure to exhaust administrative remedies; § 2.2-4025 et seq. provided for review by the circuit courts, which was due process of law. Family Home Servs., Inc. v. City of Norfolk, 72 Va. Cir. 320, 2006 Va. Cir. LEXIS 311 (N orfolk Dec. 5, 2006). Standards of review.  As petitioner did not identify any statute that allowed a party to appeal a decision of the Virginia Department of Motor Vehicles regarding the issuance and revoc ation of vanity license plates by bringing an action outside of the Virginia Administrative Procedure Act, § 2.2-4025 did not apply and the standards of review of § 2.2-4027 governed his appeal, notwithstanding the fact that he raised a constitutio nal claim. Bujno v. Commonwealth, 86 Va. Cir. 32, 2012 Va. Cir. LEXIS 143 (Chesapeake Nov. 2, 2012). Medicaid benefits denial affirmed.  Substantial evidence supported a hearing officers conclusion that there was no real agreement to transfer property in exchange for care as alleged by Medicaid applicants, and a decision denying Medicaid benefits to the applicants based on the transfer of their home to their daughter was affirmed. Moss v. Lemoine, 65 Va. Cir. 263, 2004 Va. Cir. LEXIS 135 (Spotsylvania County July 29, 2004).

akn:section.akn:heading: Right, forms, venue; date of adoption or readoption for purposes of appeal

akn:content.akn:p: Text A. Any person affected by and claiming the unlawfulness of any regulation or party aggrieved by and claiming unlawfulness of a case decision and whether exempted from the procedural requirements of Article 2 (§ 2.2-4006 et seq.) or 3 (§ 2.2-4018 et seq.) shall h ave a right to the direct review thereof by an appropriate and timely court action against the agency or its officers or agents in the manner provided by the Rules of Supreme Court of Virginia. Actions may be instituted in any court of competent jurisdic tion as provided in § 2.2-4003, and the judgments of the courts of original jurisdiction shall be subject to appeal to or review by higher courts as in other cases unless otherwise provided by law. In addition, when any regulation or case decision is the subject of an enforcement action in court, it shall also be reviewable by the court as a defense to the action, and the judgment or decree therein shall be appealable as in other cases. B. In any cour t action under this section by a person affected by and claiming the unlawfulness of any regulation on the basis that an agency failed to follow any procedure for the promulgation or adoption of a regulation specified in this chapter or in such agency s basic law, the burden shall be upon the party complaining of the agency action to designate and demonstrate the unlawfulness of the regulation by a preponderance of the evidence. If the court finds in favor of the party complaining of the agency ac tion, the court shall declare the regulation null and void and remand the case to the agency for further proceedings. C. Notwithstan ding any other provision of law or of any executive order issued under this chapter, with respect to any challenge of a regulation subject to judicial review under this chapter, the date of adoption or readoption of the regulation pursuant to § 2.2-40 15 for purposes of appeal under the Rules of Supreme Court shall be the date of publication in the Register of Regulations. History History. 1975, c. 503, § 9-6.14:16; 1986, c. 615; 1989, cc. 677, 734; 2 001, c. 844; 2014, c. 699; 2016, c. 359. Annotations The 2014 amendments. The 2014 amendment by c. 699 designated the existing provision as subsection A, deleted of this chapter following (§ 2.2-4018 et seq.), and mad e stylistic changes; and added subsection B. The 2016 amendments. The 2016 amendment by c. 359 added subsection B and redesignated former subsection B as C. Law Review. For survey of the Virginia law on administrative law for the year 2007-2008, see 43 U. Rich. L. Rev. 73 (2008). Research References. Bryson on Virginia Civil Procedure (Matthew Bender). Chapter 4 Venue. § Preferred Venue. Bryson. Michies Jurisprudence. For related discussion, see 1A M.J. Administrative Law, §§ 16, 17, 19-21. CASE NOTES Editors note. Some of the cases below were decided under former corresponding provisions. Purpose of section.  Section 62.1-44.29 is a statute providing for judicial review. The purpose of this section is to standardize court review . . . save as laws hereafter enact ed may otherwise expressly provide. Environmental Defense Fund v. Virginia State Water Control Bd., 12 Va. App. 456, 404 S.E.2d 728, 7 Va. Law Rep. 2575, 1991 Va. App. LEXIS 100 (1991). This section does not supplement § 62.1-44.29 because the latter is not a basic law conferring authority on agencies either to make regulations or decide c ases. Environmental Defense Fund v. Virginia State Water Control Bd., 12 Va. App. 456, 404 S.E.2d 728, 7 Va. Law Rep. 2575, 1991 Va. App. LEXIS 100 (1991). Applicability.  Where an agencys basic law provides expressly for Virginia Administrative Process Act coverage of certain proceedings under specified conditions and makes no provision for judicial review of other proceedings, the unmentioned proceedings are subject to the Act unless otherwise expressly excluded. May Dep't Stores Co. v. Commonwealth, Dep't of Envtl. Quality, 29 Va. App. 589, 513 S.E.2d 880, 1999 Va. App. LEXI S 236 (1999). Virginia Administrative Process Act did not apply to suit challenging executive orders and emergency temporary standards taken in response to the COVID-19 pandemi c, because the orders were issued pursuant Virginia Emergency Law, which expressly authorized the Governor to declare a state of emergency and conferred upon the Governor the broad authority to issue orders necessary to protect public health and safety i n an emergency. Va. Mfrs. Ass'n v. Northam, 74 Va. App. 1, 866 S.E.2d 27, 2021 Va. App. LEXIS 230 (2021). Prerequisites to judicial review.  A party must pursue administrative avenues that result in agency regulations and final case decisions before seeking judicial review. Fauquier County Dep't of Soc ial Servs. v. Robinson, 20 Va. App. 142, 455 S.E.2d 734, 1995 Va. App. LEXIS 332 (1995). Section 32.1-164.1 provides special statutory form for review.  The procedure provided in § 32.1-164.1 is adequate to avoid the preclusive provisions of clause (ii) of the first sentence of former § 9-6.14:16 (see now th is section). Forbes v. Kenley, 227 Va. 55, 314 S.E.2d 49, 1984 Va. LEXIS 267 (1984). This section does not create an additional basis for jurisdiction, but instead gives deference to provisions of the basic law, such as § 62.1-44.29, which makes express provisions for standing. Town of Fries v. State Water Control Bd., 13 Va. App. 213, 409 S.E.2d 634, 8 Va. Law Rep. 1093, 1991 Va. App. LEXIS 268 (1991). Jurisdiction of circuit court.  The Administrative Process Act confers upon the circuit court the power to review agency case decisions. Avery v. Virginia Retirement Sys., 33 Va. App. 210, 532 S .E.2d 348, 2000 Va. App. LEXIS 589 (2000), aff'd, 262 Va. 538, 551 S.E.2d 612, 2001 Va. LEXIS 93 (2001). A determination addressing only an agencys legal duties does not qualify for review under the Virginia Administrative Process Act. Giannoukos v. Va. Bd. of Me d. & Dep't of Health Professions, 44 Va. App. 694, 607 S.E.2d 136, 2005 Va. App. LEXIS 7 (2005). Circuit court did not err in granting the motion filed by the Virginia Board of Agriculture and Consumer Services to dismiss a citizens petition for appeal be cause the citizen failed to file notice within the 30-day period as required by Va. Sup. Ct. R. 2A:2, and thus, the circuit court never gained appellate jurisdiction to consider the merits of any assignments of error with respect to the Board; the Board s publication of the final regulation in the August 18, 2008, issue of the Register of Regulations triggered the 30-day final adoption period as required by the Virginia Administrative Process Act, subsection D of § 2.2-4013, and on September 17, 2008, the regulation was adopted and became effective, but the citizens notice of appeal was not filed until October 30, 2008. Russell v. Va. Bd. of Agric. & Consumer Servs., 59 Va. App. 86, 717 S.E.2d 413, 2011 Va. App. LEXIS 364 (2011). Because a county department of social services was a unit of county government and exempt from the Virginia Administrative Process Act, the circuit court was with out jurisdiction to hear a daughters appeal of its decision; at no time did a state agency make a finding against the daughter, and consequently, the statutory right to judicial review of the case decision of an administrative agency under the Act di d not apply. Pittsylvania Cnty. Dep't of Soc. Servs. v. Gosney, 2017 Va. App. LEXIS 119 (Va. Ct. App. May 2, 2017). Ba sic law standing requirement controls over this section.  Where the basic law contains a specific standing requirement, such as that contained in § 62.1-44.29, this requirement is controlling over the standardized cou rt review in this section. Environmental Defense Fund v. Virginia State Water Control Bd., 12 Va. App. 456, 404 S.E.2d 728, 7 Va. Law Rep. 2575, 1991 Va. App. LEXIS 100 (1991). This section gives deference to provisions of the basic law, such as § 62.1-44.29, which make express provisions for standing. This construction is supported by the concluding sentence of former § 9-6.14:3 (see now § 2.2-4000 B). Environmental Defense Fund v. Virginia State Water Control Bd., 12 Va. App. 456, 404 S.E.2d 728, 7 Va. Law Rep. 2575, 1991 Va. App. LEXIS 100 (1991). Where there is a specific provision for standing in the basic law, such provision is controlling over the standardized court review in this section. Citizens for Clean Air v. Commonwealth ex rel. State Air Pollution Control Bd., 13 Va. App. 430, 412 S.E.2d 715, 8 Va. Law Rep. 1585, 1991 Va. App. LEXIS 320 (1991). The State Air Pollution Control Law, §§ 10.1-1300 et seq., contains a specific provision with respect to standing to appeal and, thus, precludes recourse th rough the Administrative Process Act, unless the party seeking review is an owner aggrieved by a final decision of the board. Citizens for Clean Air v. Commonwealth ex rel. State Air Pollution Control Bd., 13 Va. App. 430, 412 S.E.2d 715, 8 Va. Law Rep. 1585, 1991 Va. App. LEXIS 320 (1991). Property owners had standing.  Property owners petition for appeal complied with Va. Sup. Ct. R. 2A:4(b) and contained all of the elements required by the rule. The circuit court improperly expanded the requirements of the rule when it found the owners petition for appeal insufficient to establish standing and the owners were entitled to an evidentiary hearing in circuit court on the issue of standing. Clark v. Va. Marine Res. Comm'n, 55 Va. App. 328, 685 S.E.2d 863, 2009 Va. App. LEXIS 537 (2009). Property owner lacked standing.  Circuit court properly dismissed an owners appeal of the Board for Contractors decision denying him standing as a party in a disciplinary proceeding again st a contractor because he did not establish that he was aggrieved, the Board lacked authority to determine who was responsible for correcting the violations in the owners residence, the owners right to pursue direct relief with the City Code Adm inistration was not affected, and, while he had an imme...

akn:section.akn:heading: Issues on review

akn:content.akn:p: Text The burden shall be upon the party complaining of agency action to designate and demonstrate an error of law subject to review by the court. Such issues of law include: (i) accordance with constitutional right, power, privilege, or immunity, (ii) compliance with statutory authority, jurisdiction limitations, or right as provided in the basic laws as to subject matter, the stated objectives for which regulations may be made, and the factual showing respecting violations or entitlement in connection with case decisions, (iii) observance of required procedure where any failure therein is not mere harmless error, and (iv) the substantiality of the evidentiary support for findings of fact. The determination of such fact issue shall be made upon the whole evidentiary record provided by the agency if its proceeding was required to be conducted as provided in § 2.2-4009 or 2.2-4020 or, as to subjects exempted from those s ections, pursuant to constitutional requirement or statutory provisions for opportunity for an agency record of and decision upon the evidence therein. In addition to any other judicial review provided by law, a small business, as defined in subsection A of § 2.2-4007.1, that is adversely affected or aggrieved by fi nal agency action shall be entitled to judicial review of compliance with the requirements of subdivision A 2 of § 2.2-4007.04 and § 2.2-4007.1 within one year following the date of final agency action. When the decision on review is to be made on the agency record, the duty of the court with respect to issues of fact shall be to determine whether there was substantial evidence in the agency record to support the agency decision. The duty of the court with respect to the issues of law shall be to review the agency decision de novo. The court shall enter judgment in accordance with § 2.2-4029. Where there is no agency record so required and made, any necessary facts in controversy shall be determined by the court upon the basis of the agency file, minutes, an d records of its proceedings under § 2.2-4007.01 or 2.2-4019 as augmented, if need be, by the agency pursuant to order of the court or supplemented by any allowable and necessary proofs adduced in court except that the function of the court shall be t o determine only whether the result reached by the agency could reasonably be said, on all such proofs, to be within the scope of the legal authority of the agency. Whether the fact issues are reviewed on the agency record or one made in the review action, the court shall take due account of the presumption of official regularity, the experience and specialized competence of the agency, and the purposes of the basic law under which the agency has acted. History History. 1975, c. 503, § 9-6.14:17; 1989, c. 601; 2001, c. 844; 2005, c c. 619, 682; 2007, cc. 873, 916; 2013, c. 619. Annotations The 2005 amendments. The 2005 amendments by cc. 619 and 682 are identical, and inserted the present second paragraph; and made minor stylistic changes. The 2007 amendments. The 2007 amendments by cc. 873 and 916 are identical, and substituted subdivision A 2 of § 2.2-4007.04 for subdivision H 2 of § 2.2-4007 in the second paragraph; and substituted 2.2-4007.01 for 2.2-4007 in the fourth paragraph. The 2013 amendments. The 2013 amendment by c. 619, in the third paragraph, substituted to determine for limited to ascertaining and to support the agency decision  for upon which the agency as the trier of the facts could reasonably find them to be as it did in the first sentence, and added the last two sentences. Law Review. For survey of the Virginia law on administrative law for the year 2007-2008, see 43 U. Rich. L. Rev. 73 (2008). For annual survey article, see Environmental Law, see 44 U. Rich. L. Rev. 423 (2009). For article, Civil Practice and Procedure, see 45 U. Rich. L. Rev. 183 (2010). For annual survey of Virginia law article, Administrative Law, see 47 U. Rich. L. Rev. 7 (2012). Research References. Friends Virginia Pleading and Practice (Matthew Bender). Chapter 38 Appeals to the Court of Appeals of Virginia. § 38.30 Appeals under the Administrative P rocess Act. Friend. Michies Jurisprudence. For related discussion, see 1A M.J. Administrative Law, §§ 8, 10, 16, 18, 20, 21. CASE NOTES Analysis I. In General. II. Questions of Law. III. Sufficiency of Evidence. I.In General. Editors note. Some of the cases below were decided under former corresponding provisions. Cases subject to the standard of review outlined in this section cannot be considered a trial de novo since the factual issues on appeal are controlled solely by the agency record. The reviewing court is not free to take additional evidence, even at the request of one of the parties. School Bd. v. Nicely, 12 Va. App. 1051, 408 S.E.2d 545, 8 Va. Law Rep. 367, 1991 Va. App. LEXIS 202 (1991). When the legislature created the trial de novo exclusion under former § 9-6.14:15 (see now § 2.2-4025), it contemplated agency actions whose subject matters were not subject to the standard of review set forth in this section. School Bd. v. Nicely, 12 Va. App. 1051, 408 S.E.2d 545, 8 Va. Law Rep. 367, 1991 Va. App. LEXIS 202 (1991). The scope of court review of a litigated issue under this chapter is limited to a determ ination of whether there was substantial evidence in the agency record to support the decision. State Bd. of Health v. Godfrey, 223 Va. 423, 290 S.E.2d 875, 1982 Va. LEXIS 221 (1982). Proper judicial review of boards action must not be restricted to legal issues, but must encompass all . . . proofs found within the entire record. In terrelated factual and legal issues must be considered together in the context of the entire record, with each examined under the appropriate standard of review. Environmental Defense Fund, Inc. v. Virginia State Water Control Bd., 15 Va. App. 271, 422 S .E.2d 608, 9 Va. Law Rep. 438, 1992 Va. App. LEXIS 268 (1992). Amendments did not alter standard of review.  Standard of review was not altered by the 2013 amendments; the General Assembly left intact the language that requires courts to take due account of the presumpti on of official regularity, the experience and specialized competence of the agency, and the purposes of the basic law under which the agency has acted. Women's Healthcare Assocs. v. Mucci, 64 Va. App. 420, 768 S.E.2d 720, 2015 Va. App. LEXIS 71 (2015). Plain reading of the statute, with due consideration to the words used and their context in the overall statutory scheme, and the applicable canons of statutory c onstruction, assures that the legislature effected no change to the substantial evidence standard in place prior to the 2013 amendments; the 2013 amendments to the statute did not alter the established standard for a circuit court reviewing an agency s factual determinations. Va. Ret. Sys. v. Blair, 64 Va. App. 756, 772 S.E.2d 26, 2015 Va. App. LEXIS 177 (2015). Due process rights not violate d.  Virginia Board of Medicine did not fail to afford a physician due process protections because he received notice of the allegations against him, was given the opp ortunity to cross-examine all of the witnesses against him, and was represented by counsel; the physician did not demonstrate any bias on the part of the chairman of the Board because although the Board found against him regarding record keeping issues, it did not make an adverse finding against him regarding the fraud charges. Merchia v. Va. Bd. of Med., 2018 Va. App. LEXIS 334 (Va. Ct. App. Dec. 4, 2018). Notice requirements.  Virginia Board of Medicine did not fail to afford a physician due process protections because he received notice of the allegations against him, was given the opp ortunity to cross-examine all of the witnesses against him, and was represented by counsel; the physician did not demonstrate any bias on the part of the chairman of the Board because although the Board found against him regarding record keeping issues, it did not make an adverse finding against him regarding the fraud charges. Merchia v. Va. Bd. of Med., 2018 Va. App. LEXIS 334 (Va. Ct. App. Dec. 4, 2018). Limitation on evidence.  In an agency appeal, the circuit court is not free to take additional evidence at the request of one of the parties, but is obliged to defer to the trier of fact. J.P. v. Carter, 24 Va. App. 707, 485 S.E.2d 162, 1997 Va. App. LEXIS 310 (1997). Trial court wrongly considered evidence not presented to the State Health Commissioner regarding an application for a certificate of public need because there was no showing of bias of the State Health Department, so there was no legal basis for receiving new evidence. Levine v. Arlington Med. Imaging, LLC, 2018 Va. App. LEXIS 286 (Va. Ct. App. Oct. 23, 2018). Burd en to establish insufficiency of evidence.  The burden of proof rests upon the party challenging the agency determination to show that there was not substantial evidence in the record to support it. Baumann v. Virginia Retirement Sys., 2000 Va. App. LEXIS 632 (Va. Ct. App. Aug. 29, 2000). Virginia Administrative Process Act governs dental disciplinary hearings before the Virginia Board of Dentistry. A dentist, as the complaining party, bears the bu rden of proving the Board committed an error of law under § 2.2-4027. Doe v. Va. Bd. of Dentistry, 52 Va. App. 166, 662 S.E.2d 99, 2008 Va. App. LEXIS 411 (2008). The circuit courts role.  Under the Virginia Administrative Process Act, the circuit courts role in an appeal from an agency decision is equivalent to an appellate courts role in a n appeal from a trial court.
